question.text: Compound '<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>' on nitration with dil. <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>HNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> yields two isomers <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mfenced></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></mfenced></math>. These isomers can be separated by steam distillations. Isomers <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mfenced></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></mfenced></math> show the intramolecular and intermolecular hydrogen bonding respectively. Compound <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></mfenced></math> on reaction with conc. <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>HNO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> yields a yellow compound '<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>', a strong acid. The number of oxygen atoms is present in compound '<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>'

solution.text: So, as we can see that the final proudct C is picric acid and it contain 7 oxygen atoms.
